turns.content: What are the qualifications for serving as a member of the Legislative Yuan in Taiwan?

To be eligible to serve as a member of the Legislative Yuan in Taiwan, a person must:

1. Be a Taiwanese citizen
2. Be at least 23 years of age
3. Not have been deprived of political rights
4. Not have been declared bankrupt or subject to a custodianship order
5. Not have been convicted of a crime and sentenced to a fixed term imprisonment of more than six months or a suspended sentence of more than one year and have not yet completed the sentence or been pardoned or had their right to hold public office restored
6. Have lived in Taiwan for at least two years before the election
7. Have a basic education as stipulated by law
8. Have not been removed from office due to a violation of the Constitution or related laws. 

Additionally, candidates must also meet specific requirements based on their constituency, such as being a registered voter within the constituency they are running or being a member of a political party that meets certain criteria.
Can foreign citizens who have lived in Taiwan for a long time and meet all other eligibility criteria also run for the Legislative Yuan?

No, foreign citizens cannot run for the Legislative Yuan in Taiwan, even if they have lived in Taiwan for a long time and meet all other eligibility criteria. The Constitution of Taiwan stipulates that only citizens of Taiwan are eligible to be elected as members of the Legislative Yuan.
Why is it that only Taiwanese citizens can run for the Legislative Yuan? Is there any particular reason for this?

There are several reasons why only Taiwanese citizens can run for the Legislative Yuan in Taiwan. 

Firstly, the Legislative Yuan is a political institution that represents the citizens of Taiwan and makes decisions on their behalf. Hence, it is important that only citizens, who have a stake in the country and its future, are allowed to hold these positions.

Secondly, the Constitution of Taiwan defines citizenship as a requirement for holding public office, including being a member of the Legislative Yuan. This requirement serves as a way to ensure that those holding public office are loyal to the country and its people.

Thirdly, citizenship is also important in ensuring that those who hold public office are subject to the laws, regulations, and policies of the country. In general, foreigners are subject to their country's laws and regulations, which may not necessarily align with those of Taiwan.

Overall, the restriction on candidacy in the Legislative Yuan to only Taiwanese citizens is meant to ensure that the country's political leaders are loyal to and invested in Taiwan's future.
